title: Payoff auto loan outside of the chapter 13
question: I have one auto loan within Chapter 13 plan which already made 50th payments; the other auto loan is outside of the plan and has 18 months payment remaining (72 months loan). Can I payoff the outside auto loan now? Will that affect my final discharge at the end of my chapter 13?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Car loan
answers:
I agree with Stuart and the other attorneys that said there are consequences to your actions in paying off your loan early. Since 2005, all B/R attorneys have been subject to a gag rule about what B/R advice they can give and what B/R advice they can no longer give, post 2005. That is, we are barred from giving you advice that, if followed, would result in you owing less money to a Creditor than you otherwise would have owed that Creditor, if you had not followed the advice from the attorney as your course of action. You, on your own, and NOT as a result of advice from your lawyer, can make any decision that you believe is in your best interests. Just do not do it because your lawyer told you to. They will not do so.
BTW, my view is that attorneys work for Clients, and the Clients are always the Boss, So no matter what I said, how could I tell the Boss what to do? How do we know this is true? Because the Boss always signs a paycheck and gives it to the employee. That action is the hallmark of the attorney-Client relationship.
Here, you are crossing a wide stream, and are 80% of the way to the far bank. You are well-seated on a predictable, reliable, horse, and at present, all but your boots are dry. So, does a prudent and wise rider spur the horse and create a reaction, or does he just stay balanced and ride across to the other side? You live out West, what is the right answer? No B/R advice here, just horse talk. Good luck.

Depending on what percentage plan you are in, paying off your auto loan may cause your plan payment to increase. Chapter 13s are incredibly complex. If you do not have an attorney, you should hire one before making any drastic changes in your financial situation during a chapter 13.

As you can see by the answers given by Mr. Primus and Mr. Steingraber, there can be multiple issues arise every time you do something that can effect your debt structure or your assets while in an active chapter 13 case.

How certain issues are handled can vary substantially from one court to another and can vary between judges and trustees in the same district or division. You should never take any action related to your finances and/or assets in your chapter 13 case without first getting the advices of an experienced chapter 13 bankruptcy attorney that practices before the judge and trustee assigned to your case.

If you have an attorney, you should go over your concerns with him/her. If you do not have an attorney, you should consider retaining an attorney before taking any action such as paying off a debt, even if that debt is being paid outside the chapter 13 plan.

You can payoff the car loan outside the plan, but be prepared when the Trustee files its motion to increase your plan payments by the amount of the loan payment no longer in your budget. Depending on the Plan details, unsecured creditors may receive a larger dividend if you have a larger Plan payment.

You can payoff the car at this time and it will not cause a problem with getting the discharge. Another thing to consider is paying off the chapter 13. In Contra Costa County the system will let you payoff a chapter 13 once you get to the 55th month.
